The Sutra of King Poluo (Poluo King's Past Life) (11) The Sutra of King Poluo In the past, there was a king named Poluo in the country of Varanasi. He ruled the country with benevolence, abolished weapons, eliminated punishments, destroyed prisons, and there were no cries on the roads. The multitude found their place, the country was prosperous, and the people flourished. The gods praised his benevolence.
The royal city was 400 li long and wide, with a circumference of 1,600 li. The king fed the people within this area every day, all according to their wishes.
The neighboring countries heard that his country was prosperous and disasters had been eliminated, and he consulted with his ministers, saying:
'That country is prosperous and the people are wealthy and happy. I want to obtain it. If we go, we will surely conquer it.'
The ministers and concubines all said:
'We joyfully follow the king's wish.'
They then raised an army and went to the country of benevolence.
The ministers of the kind country reported this and wanted to resist.
The kind king was stern and said:

'With my one person's body, I would kill the bodies of millions of people. I love my one person's life and destroy the lives of millions of people. Eating twice a day and wearing several clothes, what dispute is there with the times?
And to take away the virtue of spring and take the leftovers of the jackal and wolf?
I would rather give up my one life, not give up my great aspiration, and forgive myself and comfort all beings, which is the kindness of Heaven.'
Quan said to the ministers:
'Each of you retreat, and discuss again tomorrow.'
At night, he crossed the city wall, fled, and entered the mountains to sit under a tree.
There was a brahman who came, sixty years old, and asked the king:
'Is the king of the kind country well and without trouble?'
He replied:
'That king has already lost his life.'
When the brahman heard this, he fell to the ground and wailed in grief.
The king asked him:
Why do you have such deep compassion?
He replied:
I heard that the king is benevolent to all beings and as nourishing as Indra, so I ran to take refuge.
But he is now withered and lost, and I am old and poor.
The king said:
That benevolent king is me.
The king of the neighboring country heard that my country is prosperous, with a thriving population and abundant treasures, and ordered his warriors, saying:
Whoever obtains my head will be rewarded with a thousand male and female servants, a thousand horses, a thousand cows, and a thousand jin of gold and silver each.
Now you take my head, with the golden crown and sword as proof, go to that king, and the rewards will be abundant. It can be a source of wealth for generations to come.
My heart is delighted.
He replied:
I would rather die than do such an unrighteous and rebellious deed.
The king said:
This old man relies on me to live, yet you are causing him to be poor?
I now offer my head to you, to free you from guilt.'
He then bowed to the ten directions, and with tears flowing, vowed:
'For those in danger, I will bring them peace;
For those who turn away from truth and toward evil, I will cause them to take refuge in the Three Jewels.ğŸ”½Now I free your son from poverty and allow him to be guiltless.'
He drew his sword and cut off his head to save the son from danger.
The brahman then put the head on the sword and went to the king. The king asked the old minister:
'You, the king's powerful minister, were captured by this son?'
The old minister bowed his head to the ground, wailing in grief and unable to respond.
He asked the brahman again, and the brahman recounted the details.
The people in the streets cried out in the alleys, some vomited blood, some stopped breathing and looked like corpses.
The king, ministers, and soldiers, from the highest to the lowest, all wailed.
The king looked up to the sky and sighed:
'Am I without virtue?
The remaining son of the kind king.
Take the body and head of the kind king, connect them with gold foil, and have his body sit on the palace, for thirty-two years as the heavenly king, later establish his son as the king.
The neighboring countries all love him like a son.
The kind king's life ended and he was immediately reborn in the heavens.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:ğŸ”½The kind king was me.
The king of the neighboring country was MaudgalyÄyana.
The group of ministers of that country are now the bhiká¹£us.
The bodhisattva's practice of giving with boundless kindness and generosity is like this.

The Sutra of the King of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ« (JÄtaka of King Karandhama) (12) The Sutra of the King of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ« Long ago, in the country of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, there was a prince named Karandhama, with two brothers. When their father, the king, passed away, they vied for the country, and no one could establish himself.
The elder brother took his wife and fled to the mountains to study the Way, stopping by the riverside.
At that time, there was a criminal in another country whose hands and feet were cut off by the state, his nose and ears were severed, and he was thrown into the river in a broken boat.
The criminal cried out to the heavens.
The Daoist heard this and was moved to pity, saying:
What kind of person is he?
His suffering is extremely severe.
To widely practice compassion, forgive oneself, risk one's life, and save the suffering of all beings - this is the deed of a great person.

He threw himself into the water, stirred the waves and cut through the current, pulled the boat to the shore, carried him back to his home, diligently cared for him, and when his wounds healed and his life was saved,
he took care of him for four years with untiring compassion.
His wife was licentious and had no scruples, having an affair with the criminal. She plotted to kill her husband, saying:
Kill him and I will live with you.
The criminal said:
He is a virtuous person, how can I kill him?
The wife's words were as before. The criminal said:
I have no hands or feet, I cannot kill him.
The wife said:
'Sit down, I have a plan.'
Pretending to be sick, she told her husband:
'This must be the work of the mountain god. I want to resolve it.
Tomorrow, I will follow you to seek blessings.'
Her husband said:
'Very good!'
The next day, they went to the mountainside, forty li high, with three sides of sheer cliffs, terrifying to behold.
The wife said:
'The ritual method is, you stand facing the sun, and I will perform the sacrifice.'
The husband immediately stood facing the sun, and the wife feigned to walk around him several times, then pushed him off the mountainside.
Halfway down the mountain, there was a tree with dense, soft leaves. The Daoist grabbed a branch and stood there, surviving by eating the sweet fruits of the tree.
Beside the tree, there was a turtle that also ate the fruits daily. Seeing a person in the tree, it was afraid and did not dare approach.
After five days of hunger, it recklessly went for the fruits, and neither was harmed. They eventually rubbed against each other.
The Daoist master rode on a turtle, but the turtle was startled and jumped off the ground;
The celestial spirits protected him, and both of them were unharmed.
He then returned to his home country, and his younger brother ceded the country to his elder brother.
The elder brother, being magnanimous and compassionate, saved and delivered all beings.

The king governed his country, and as soon as the sun rose, he gave alms. Within a distance of four hundred li, people, carriages, horses, and various treasures, food and drink were freely provided, and in the east, west, south, and north, kindness and nurture were like this.
The king's fame and virtue spread throughout the ten directions, and people praised his virtue.
The wife thought her husband was dead. No one in the country recognized her. She carried a log on her back and entered the country, declaring:
My husband and I have suffered from the decline of the world. Our bodies are withered and emaciated. We come to beg for alms out of faith in the king's compassionate grace.
The people of the country admired her for this and instructed her:
The king is universally compassionate and nurtures all beings. Tomorrow he will come out of the east gate to give alms.
You should go against the crowd. Because of your good conduct, he will surely give you much.
The next day, he begged the king for permission, and the king silently understood. He told the group of ministers the wife's past and present.
A minister said:
We should burn her.
Another minister said:
We should cut her.
The minister in charge of law said:
Among crimes, none is greater than abandoning righteousness and entering into evil, becoming a perpetrator of rebellion.
We should nail the criminal to the back of the witch and make her carry him for a long time.
The group of ministers all said:
Excellent!
Following her preferences, we have clearly grasped her.
The king transformed the people with the ten wholesome deeds, and none did not rejoice and support him.
The king and his ministers all were reborn in the heavens after their lives ended;
the criminal couple entered hell after their deaths.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The king at that time was me.
The criminal was Devadatta, and the wife was the woman with the pregnant belly.
The bodhisattva's practice of giving with compassion and wisdom is like this.

The Sutra of King Sarandada (Sarandada Jataka) (13) The Sutra of King Sarandada In the past, there was a king named Sarandada, which means 'giving everything,' who did not go against people's wishes when they asked for things.
His giving was like this, and his name was heard in the eight directions, known by all.
At that time, Manjushri wanted to test him, so he transformed into a young brahmin who came from a different country to the king's palace gate and said to the gatekeeper:
'I have come from far away and want to see the great king.'
At that time, the gatekeeper reported this.
The king was very happy and immediately came out to welcome him, like a son seeing his father, and prostrated before him. He then invited him to sit down.
He asked:
'Where did the Wayfarer come from?
Have you not become tired from traveling on the road?'
The mind of passing away said:
'I heard of the king's merits in another country, so I came to see him. Now I wish to beg for something.'
The king said:
'Very good!
Whatever you wish to obtain, do not hesitate.
Now I am called the Giver of All, what do you seek?
' The brÄhmaá¹‡a said:
'I do not need anything else, I wish to obtain the king's body to be my slave, and the king's wife to be my maid.
If you can do this, then follow me.'
The king was overjoyed and replied:
'Very good!
Now my body can certainly be obtained, I wish to belong to the Way and serve you.
As for the wife, she is the daughter of a great king, I shall go ask her.'
Then the king entered and said to the wife:
'There is now a young and handsome monk who has come from afar. He wants to beg for my body to make me his slave. Now he also wants to ask for you to be his maid. What should we do?'
His wife said:
'What did the king reply?'
The king said:
'I have already agreed to be his slave, but I have not agreed to you.'
At that time, the wife said:
'The king has abandoned you and has his own way. He does not think of saving me.'
At that time, the wife followed the king out and said to the monk:
'Please accept my body to serve the monk.'
At that time, the brÄhman again said to the king:
'Is it really so?
I now wish to leave.'
The king said to the monk:
'Since I was born, I have never regretted giving, only to the monk.'
The mind of passing away said:
'You should follow me, all barefoot, not wearing shoes, acting like a slave, not being disobedient.'
The king and his wife both said:
'Yes, we will obey.
We will follow the master's instructions and dare not disobey.'
Then the brÄhman took the slaves and went on their way.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« then transformed someone to replace the king and the queen's body, managing the affairs of state as usual.
The king's wife was originally the daughter of a great king, upright and unparalleled, with soft hands and feet. She grew up in the deep palace and had never experienced cold or hardship.

Moreover, she was heavily pregnant for several months. As she walked behind the master, her whole body ached and the soles of her feet were wounded. She could not go on and was exhausted, staying behind.
At that time, the brÄhman turned back and scolded her, saying:
'Now that you are a slave, you should act like a slave. You cannot act with your former airs.
The wife knelt and said:
I dare not.
I was just a little tired and rested for a while.
The husband said:
Come quickly, follow me.
They went to the market in the country and sold the male and female slaves separately. They were taken by different masters, separated by several li.
At that time, an elder bought this male slave and made him guard the house. He was ordered to collect taxes from those who buried things and was not allowed to move around recklessly.
As for the female slave, her new master's wife was very jealous and made her work day and night without any rest.
After several days, the female slave became pregnant and gave birth to a son. The wife became angry and said:
You are a slave, how can you have this child?
She ordered the female slave to kill the child.
Following her master's wife's instructions, she killed the child and buried it.
She went to where the male slave was and they met. She said:
I gave birth to a son, but he has already died today.
I did not bring any money. Can I just bury it here now?
The slave replied:
The master is very urgent!
If this is heard by others, the blame will not be small.
You should quickly take it away and look for another place. You don't need to stay here.
Although the king and his wife were able to see each other, they did not speak of their hardships and each had no resentment in their hearts.

In this way, in a short moment, it was as if in a dream. The king and his wife naturally returned to their original country, sitting in the main hall of the inner palace, as before, no different. The various ministers, concubines, and court ladies were all as before, and the prince they gave birth to also naturally came back to life.
The king and his wife inwardly doubted, wondering what had caused this.
Manjushri was sitting on a seven-jeweled lotus flower in the sky, manifesting his physical appearance and praising, saying:
Excellent!
Now your giving is sincere like this.
The king and his wife joyfully prostrated themselves before him.

MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« expounded the Dharma for them. The three thousand worlds shook greatly. All the people of the country were inspired, and they all gave rise to the intention to achieve supreme, perfect enlightenment. The king and his wife immediately attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
The king at that time was none other than I myself.ğŸ”½The queen at that time is now YaÅ›odharÄ.
The prince at that time is now RÄhula.
The Buddha said:
Ä€nanda!

In my past lives, I gave generously in this way. For the sake of all people, I did not begrudge my life or body, and for countless eons, I had no regrets or remorse, and I did not seek any glory or reward. I attained perfect enlightenment on my own.
The bodhisattva practices giving with the perfection of kindness and compassion in this way.

14. The Sudaá¹ƒsa SÅ«tra (Sudaá¹ƒsa Prince's Past Life) (14) The Sudaá¹ƒsa SÅ«tra In the past, the king of the Yebo country was called Shesway, his name was Saja, he ruled the country with righteousness, and the people had no resentment.

The king had a prince named Sudaá¹ƒsa, whose appearance and demeanor were unparalleled in the world. His kindness and filial piety were difficult to match. He universally protected with the four immeasurable minds, and his words did not harm others.
The king had one son whom he treasured infinitely. The prince served his parents just as he would serve the heavens.
Those who knew him came and said, 'He always wishes to give generously and save all beings, so that in his future lives he will receive inexhaustible blessings.
The foolish do not see the changes brought about by impermanence and consider them to be something that can be relied upon.
The wise illuminate the existence of the five families and thus uphold the practice of giving.
The Buddhas of the ten directions, the Pratyekabuddhas, and the Venerable Ones who are free from attachment, all praise giving as the treasure of the world.'
The prince then greatly promoted universal giving, and his kindness extended to all beings.
Those who wanted clothes and food, he would immediately give them to them. Gold, silver, various treasures, carriages, horses, fields, and houses, there was nothing he would not give.
His reputation spread far and wide, and the four seas praised him.
The father king had a white elephant, whose majestic martial power could crush sixty elephants. When the enemy country came to fight, the elephant would always win.
The kings discussed:
'The prince is wise and holy, and there is nothing he will not give.
Send the eight brahmanas to the prince, to beg for the white elephant.
If he can give it, I will greatly thank you.'

Receiving the order, they immediately set out, wearing deerskin robes, carrying water jars, and traveling far with their staffs, passing through more than a thousand counties and prefectures, to the country of Yebo. They stood at the palace gate with their staffs, and said to the guards:
'We have heard that the prince gives to the poor and benefits all beings, so we have come from afar to beg for what we lack.'
The guards then entered and reported the matter to the king.
The prince heard this and joyfully rushed to welcome him, just like a son seeing his parent. He bowed his head to the feet of the brÄhman and comforted him, saying:
Where have you come from? How is your body?
What do you seek? To stand on one foot?
The brÄhman replied:
The prince's virtue and light are heard in the eight directions, reaching up to the blue heavens and down to the yellow springs. He is lofty like Mount Tai, and none do not sigh in admiration.
You are the son of the gods and humans. Your words must be trustworthy.
If you truly practice giving and do not go against the wishes of the multitude, I now wish to beg for the white elephant on top of the lotus flowers, the elephant named RÄjagá¹›ha MahÄdatta.
The prince said:
Excellent!
Only you, the gentlemen, can freely seek gold, silver, and various treasures without difficulty for yourselves.
He then ordered his attendants to quickly saddle the white elephant with golden and silver harnesses and lead it to him.
He held the elephant harness on the left and a golden jar in the right hand to wash the brÄhman's hands, kindly and joyfully giving him the elephant.
The brÄhmaá¹‡a was greatly delighted, and after finishing his blessings, they both mounted the elephant and left with smiles.
The prime minister and all the officials were not pleased, and they all said:
This elephant is a mighty beast, and the country relies on it for peace. When enemies clash in battle, it will surely shake and flee.
Now that it is given to our enemy, what can we rely on?
They all presented their opinions, saying:
As for the white elephant, its power can crush sixty elephants. This is the country's treasure for repelling enemies.

But the prince gives it to a heavy enemy. The treasury is empty day by day. The prince indulges in giving without stopping. In just a few years, we ministers fear that the entire country's wives and children will become objects of giving.
The king, hearing their words, was grim for a long time and said:
The prince delights in the Buddha's way, providing for the poor and needy, and nurturing all beings with kindness, as the foremost practice.
Even if he is prohibited or punished, this would be unrighteous.
The hundred officials all said:
The teaching of cutting and polishing is without error, but if punishment is cruel, we dare to report it.
Banish him from the country and place him in the fields. For ten years, let him feel ashamed and repent. This is the wish of your ministers.
The king then sent an envoy to proclaim to him:
An elephant is a national treasure. Why do you give it to an enemy?
I cannot bear to punish you, but quickly leave the country.
The envoy received the order and proclaimed it to him in this way.
The prince replied:
I dare not disobey the will of heaven.
I only wish to beg for alms to relieve the needy for seven days, and then leave the country without regret.
The envoy reported this, and the king said:
Go quickly, I will not listen to you.
The envoy returned and said:
The king's order cannot be disobeyed.
The prince repeated:
I dare not disobey the will of heaven.
I have my own private wealth, and I dare not encroach on the country.
The envoy reported this again, and the king then listened to him.
The prince joyfully ordered his attendants:
'If there are any poor people in the country, encourage them to come quickly and give them whatever they desire without refusal.
The official ranks, fields, houses, wealth and treasures of the country are all like illusions and dreams, and will not last.

' The people, both high and low, rushed to the palace gate. The prince gave them food and drink, clothing, the seven treasures, and all kinds of precious things, according to their desires. After giving them all he had, the poor became rich.
His wife was named Manti, the daughter of a king. Her appearance was radiant, unmatched in the country. From head to toe, she was adorned with the seven treasures and necklaces.
He said to his wife:
'Rise and listen to my words. The king has exiled me to Danxuan Mountain, with a limit of ten years.
Do you know this?'
His wife was startled and rose. Seeing the prince's tears, she said:
'What crime have you committed that you are being banished, abandoning the glory of the kingdom to dwell in the deep mountains?'
He replied to his wife,
Because of my giving, the country has become depleted. I gave my famous elephant and treasures to my enemies.
The king and the ministers are angry and have expelled me.
His wife then made a vow,
May the country be prosperous and the king, ministers, and people be wealthy and long-lived. You should only set your resolve on the mountains and wilds, attain the Way, and make vast vows.
The prince said,
Those mountains and wilds are places of fear. Tigers, wolves, and harmful beasts are difficult to stop.
There are also poisonous insects, demons, ghosts, lightning, thunder, wind, rain, clouds, and fog, which are extremely frightening.
The cold and heat are excessive, and the trees are difficult to rely on. Thorny brambles and gravel are not suitable for you.

You are the king's son, born in glory and raised in the inner palace. Your clothes are fine and soft, your food and drink are delicious, you sleep under canopies and curtains, and various entertainments fill your ears. Your wishes are indulged.
Now dwelling in the mountains and marshes, sleeping on grass mats, eating fruits and nuts, which are unbearable for humans, how can you endure it?'
His wife said:
'Fine and soft jeweled curtains and delicious food, what benefit is there to oneself?
And to be separated from the prince while living?

When the great king goes out, he uses a banner as a sign, fire uses smoke as a sign, and a woman uses her husband as a sign. I rely on the prince like a child relies on his parents. When the prince was in the country, he gave alms to the four directions, and I would immediately share the vow.
Now, to pass through dangers and yet remain in charge of the honor, how could that be benevolent conduct?
If there are those who come to beg and do not see the prince, the feeling in the heart will be cut off, and death is certain.'
The prince said:
'People from distant countries come to beg for wives and children, I have no contrary thoughts.
You are emotionally attached, if you violate the way of kindness and completely cut off great nourishment, it will destroy my heavy responsibility.'
His wife said:
'The prince's giving is seen by the world as rare. He should fulfill his great vow and not be lax.
For hundreds of thousands of myriads of generations, no one has been like you, reaching the Buddha's heavy responsibility. I dare not disobey.'
The prince said:
'Good!'
He then took his wife and children to bid farewell to his mother. He bowed to the ground and said with pity:
'Please abandon heavy thoughts and preserve your jade-like body. In state affairs, hold the reins and often give kind advice, do not act freely and wrong the people of heaven.
You must endure what is unbearable, and forbearance is a treasure.'
When his mother heard his farewell words, she turned to her attendants and said:
'My body is like a stone, my heart is like hard iron. Now I have a son who is being expelled. What heart do I have?

Before I had a son, I made a vow to seek offspring. When I conceived, I was like a tree bearing flowers, and I needed them to come to fruition. Heaven did not take away my vow to have a son. Now that I have raised him to maturity, I will be separated from him at birth?
The jealous ones in the palace were delighted and no longer respected each other.

The prince's wife and children bowed and left. No one in the palace, from the highest to the lowest, did not weep. They left the city with the hundred officials and people, sadly taking leave. All of them whispered:
The prince is the country's sacred spirit and the most revered of all treasures. What hearts do his parents have to banish him?
The prince sat outside the city, thanking those who had seen him off, and sent them back to their homes.
The people all bowed and wept, some rolling on the ground and crying out to heaven, the sound shaking the country.
With his wife, he advanced on the road, knowing he was far from his homeland, and sat under a tree.

A brahman came from afar to beg. He untied his precious clothes, his wife's and children's pearls and gems, and gave them all as gifts. He let his wife and children ascend the carriage, holding the reins and leaving.
Just as he was about to set out on the road, he encountered another brahman who came to beg for his horse. He gave the horse as a gift;
he himself pulled the carriage from the shaft and advanced on the road.
He also encountered a brahman who came to beg for his carriage, so he immediately got down with his wife and children and gave him the carriage.
The prince's carriage, horse, clothes, jewels, and various belongings were all gone without a trace left, leaving his wife to carry the girl and himself to carry the boy.

When he was in the country, he gave away famous elephants, jeweled carriages, and horses. Even when he was slandered and expelled, he never became angry or regretted it. With a harmonious heart, he followed his wife and joyfully entered the mountains.
After twenty-one days, they reached Mount Dantuo.

The prince saw that the mountain had lush trees, flowing springs, beautiful water, and abundant sweet fruits. Ducks, geese, and mandarin ducks played among them, and hundreds of birds chirped harmoniously and sang melodiously.
The prince looked at it and said to his wife, '
You see this mountain, with trees reaching to the heavens, few broken branches, flocks of birds singing melodiously, springs everywhere, and many fruits to serve as food and drink;
Only the Way is to be pursued, do not go against your vow.'
The mountain ascetics all guarded their integrity and loved learning. There was an ascetic named Ajita who had been in the mountains for a long time and possessed profound and wonderful virtues.
He immediately went with his wife and children to pay homage, bowed, and stood with palms joined. He said to the ascetic:
I am bringing my wife and children here to study the Way. I wish you would bestow your great compassion and teach me to fulfill my aspirations.
The ascetic instructed him, and the prince followed suit. He built a hut with firewood and grass, tied his hair in a topknot, wore hemp clothes, ate fruits, and drank from the spring.
The son was named Yeli, wearing clothes made of small grass, following his father in coming and going;
The daughter was named Kai Nayan, wearing clothes made of deer skin, following her mother in coming and going.
Staying in the mountains for one night, the heavens increased the spring water, its taste becoming more and more sweet, and medicinal trees and famous fruits grew luxuriantly.
Later, there was an old and poor brahman from the country of Kuru. His wife was in the prime of life, with a youthful and upright appearance. She was carrying a jar and going to draw water.
On the way, she encountered a young man who blocked her path and said teasingly:ğŸ”½The water is in the jar, and the jar is in the water. How can you draw the water?
'You live in poverty and have nothing to sustain yourself, coveting that old man's wealth in hopes of returning home.
That old man studies the Way, but his inner understanding is not thorough. In the annals of teaching and transforming, he hopes to accomplish one person.
He is single-mindedly foolish and obstinate. What do you intend to covet?

His facial features are ugly and black, his nose is flat, his body is twisted, his face is wrinkled and his lips are thin, his speech is stammering, and his two eyes are blue. His appearance is like a ghost, and his entire body has no good qualities. Who would not despise him?
Will your family not be ashamed and disgusted?'
When the wife heard her husband's words, she shed tears and said:
'I see that old man's hair and beard are pure white, like frost on a tree.
Morning and evening I hope in my heart for him to die soon.
If my wish is not fulfilled immediately, what can I do?'
She returned to her husband and told him everything, saying:
'You have male and female slaves, and I do not go to draw water.
If it is like this now, I will leave you.'
The groom said:
I am poor, how can I afford to give you servants?
His wife said:
I heard that the great giver named SudÄna, with his great kindness and generosity to the masses, has exhausted his country's resources.
The king and his ministers have exiled him to the mountains.
If you beg him, he will give you his two children.
The wife spoke this way many times, and it was difficult to disobey a beloved wife, so he followed her words, went to the country of Yebo, and said at the palace gate:
Is the prince well?
The guards reported this to the king.
When the king heard these words, his heart was blocked, and he wept with tears flowing. After a while, he said:
The prince was banished only for the sake of people like this;
and now he has come again?
He invited them in and asked the reason.
They replied:
The prince's kindness is praised far and wide, so we have come from afar to seek refuge.
The king said:ğŸ”½The prince is now in the mountains, how can I give you his children?
'The prince has given away all his treasures and now lives in the deep mountains, with insufficient clothing and food. How can he bestow his daughter?'
He replied:
'His virtue is lofty and far-reaching. I have long admired him from afar. I value seeing his radiant countenance. Even if I die without regret,
the king sent someone to show him the way.
On the road, he met a hunter and said:
'You have traveled through the mountains. Have you seen the prince?'
The hunter, who knew the reason for the prince's banishment, became angry and scolded him, saying:
'I will cut off your head if you ask about the prince!'
The brahman was embarrassed and afraid, and said:ğŸ”½'I will surely be killed by you!
I must use a trick on him.'
He said:
'The king and his ministers are calling for the prince to return to the country and become king.'
He replied:
'Very good!'
Delighted, he showed him the way.
From afar, he saw a small house. The prince also saw them coming.
The two children saw this and were terrified in their hearts. The brothers both said:
Our father is still generous, and this son has come. The wealth is exhausted and cannot be provided. He will certainly give us brothers to him.
They took each other's hands and fled together.
The mother had dug a hole to hide in, and the two children entered it, covering it with firewood on top. They warned each other:
If our father calls, do not respond.
The prince looked up and asked them to sit in front, and placed fruit juice in front of them.
After eating the fruit and drinking, he comforted and praised them, saying:
You must be tired from the long journey.
They replied:
We have come from there, and our whole bodies are aching and painful. We are also very hungry and thirsty.
The prince's radiant virtue is praised in the eight directions. His lofty and lofty virtue shines far.
He is like a great mountain. Which of the celestial gods and earthly spirits does not greatly admire him? Now we have come from afar to the end, hoping to extend our meager lives.
The prince was deeply moved and said:
The wealth is exhausted and there is nothing left to spare.
The brahman said:
You can give me your two children to support me in my old age.
He replied:
You have come from afar to ask for my children, I cannot go against your wishes.
The prince called them, and the brothers were afraid.
They said to each other:
When our father calls for us, he must be giving us to the ghost.
They disobeyed the order and did not respond.
The prince hid in the pit, and when he removed the firewood and looked, the children came out and embraced their father, trembling and weeping, crying out and saying:
He is a ghost!
He is not a brahman!
I have seen many brahmans, but none have looked like this. Do not use us as food for the ghost.
Why is it taking so long for our mother to return from picking fruit?
Today we will definitely die, eaten by the ghost.
When our mother returns and asks for us, it will be like a cow searching for its calf, running wildly and wailing in grief.
Our father will surely regret it.
The prince said:
'I have always given generously without the slightest regret. I will give to you, do not go against my wishes.'
The brahman said:
'You are universally kind and generous, but if the mother of the child returns, she will ruin your great kindness and go against my original vow. It is better to leave early.'
The prince said:
'You came from afar seeking a child, I will never go against your wishes, you can quickly leave.'
The prince washed with his right hand and held the child with his left hand, and handed him to the brahman.
The brahman said:
'I am old and weak, and the child's mother will abandon him and run away. How can I obtain him?
The prince's great kindness is to tie him up and hand him over.'

The prince held the child and had him tied up by the brahman. He held the end of the rope himself. The two children fell to the ground and rolled in front of their father. They cried out to their mother, saying:
'May the gods of heaven and earth, the spirits of mountains and trees, have pity and tell our mother to come back.
The two children are kind to people, you should quickly give up those fruits, and we can meet each other.
Moved by the mother's grief, the mountain god felt pity and made a loud rumbling sound like thunder.

The mother was picking fruits when she suddenly became anxious. She looked up at the blue sky but saw no clouds or rain. Her right eye twitched and her left armpit itched. Her two breasts started to leak milk. The mother thought to herself:
This is a very strange occurrence!
What should I do with these fruits?
I must quickly return to check on my children, something must have happened to them!
She put down the fruits and rushed back home, as anxious as if she were crazy.
Indra thought to himself:
The Bodhisattva's resolve is lofty, he wishes to fulfill his great vow and heavy responsibility, but his wife's arrival may destroy his lofty resolve.
He transformed into a lion and crouched in the path.
The wife said:

'You are the king of beasts, and I am also the prince among men. We both live in this mountain. I have two children who are still very young. They are waiting for me to come back in the morning before they eat.'
The lion avoided her, and the woman was able to continue on her way.
She turned back and transformed into a white wolf in front of her. The woman's words were the same as before, and the wolf also avoided her.
She then transformed into a tiger. When the brahman was far away, she finally retreated.

The woman returned and saw the prince sitting alone. She said fearfully, 'My children are like this, yet now you sit alone. The children always look forward to seeing me return with fruit. They run towards me, fall down, get up again, and jump and laugh, saying:
Mother has returned! The hungry children are full!
But now I don't see them. Have you given them to someone else?
When I sit, the children stand, each on my left and right. They see dust on my body and compete to wipe it off.
Now the children don't come, and I don't see where they are. To whom have you given them?
You should tell me quickly.
Praying to Heaven and Earth, it is truly difficult to say why I have now given birth to a good son.

Now, the children's playthings, clay elephants, clay cows, clay horses, clay pigs, and various skillful objects are scattered all over the ground. Seeing this, my heart is moved, and I am about to go mad, thinking that tigers, wolves, ghosts, spirits, thieves, and bandits will devour them!
Quickly release this knot, I will surely die!'
The prince spoke after a long time, saying:
'A brahman came and asked for the two children, saying:
My years are exhausted and my life is weak, I wish to save myself.
I gave them to him out of kindness.'
When the wife heard these words, she was moved and fell to the ground, rolling around in sorrowful wailing and tears, saying:
'If it is really as you dreamed, in one night I dreamed of seeing an old, emaciated, poor brahman cutting off my two breasts and quickly running off with them;
This must be it now.'
She wailed and called out to Heaven, shaking the entire mountain valley.
She said:
'If your son is like this, should you seek it in the same way?'
The prince saw his wife's sorrowful wailing and said to her:
I originally pledged to you to honor filial piety and follow my will for the great path, to save all beings without seeking anything in return, and my words were very clear.
But now you are sorrowful and wailing, disturbing my mind?
His wife said:
How much hardship has the prince endured in seeking the Way?
Husbands in the world value their wives and children, and are not free from them, how much more so for one who is honored by people?
She said:
What I seek will surely be obtained, like omniscience.
The Emperor of Heaven and the various gods discussed together, saying:
The prince is magnanimous in spreading the Way and giving universally without covering up. Let's test him with his wife to see what his mind is like.
Shakra transformed into a brahman and came before him, saying:

'I have heard that you, sir, possess the benevolence of Heaven and Earth, universally saving all beings and giving without resistance. Therefore, I have come to entrust my feelings to you. Your wife is virtuous and chaste, and her virtue is widely renowned. Therefore, I have come to beg for her. If you are willing to bestow her upon me, that would be excellent.'
He replied:
'Very good!'
He held the Brahmin's hand with his right hand, and with his left hand took his wife and was about to give her to him.
The gods praised him, saying, 'Excellent!' Heaven and earth suddenly shook greatly, and humans and ghosts were all startled.
The Brahmin said:
'Stop!
I will not take her.'
He replied:
'Is there anything wrong with this wife?
There is no evil at all in women. The propriety of women is the foremost thing.

However, her father, the king, has only this daughter. She has served her husband with utmost propriety, not avoiding muddy roads. Her clothing and food are plain, not seeking fine delicacies. She is diligent, vigorous, and her appearance and radiance surpass others.
I am delighted that you take her. Removing worries is the best.'
The brÄhman said:
The virtue and excellence of my wife is truly as you say, I respectfully accept it.
I entrust her to you, do not give her to others.
He also said:
I am the Heavenly Emperor Åšakra, not an ordinary person of the world, I have come to test you.
You still revere the Buddha's wisdom, your virtue is difficult to match. Now, what do you wish for? I will grant whatever you seek.
The prince said:
I wish to attain great wealth, always enjoy giving without greed surpassing now;
May my father, the king, and the ministers and people of the country think of each other and wish to see each other.
Heavenly Emperor Åšakra said:
Good!
He immediately disappeared.
The brÄhman was delighted to have attained his wish, he walked without feeling tired, he pulled the two children wanting to look at them.

The children were the king's grandchildren, accustomed to luxury and freedom, separated from their two parents, bound by ropes with wounds from the ties, crying and calling for their mother, whipped and dragged along.
The brahmin took a nap, and the two children ran away, sinking into the pond, covered by lotus leaves, with water insects entangled in their bodies.
When he woke up and searched for them, he found the children again;
he beat them with a stick, blood flowing on the red ground.
The celestial spirits took pity on them, untied their bonds, healed their wounds, and made sweet fruits grow, softening the ground.
The brothers picked the fruits and passed them to each other, saying:
These fruits are as sweet as the fruits in the garden, and this soft ground is like the soft cloth on the king's side.
The brothers supported each other, looked up to the sky, called out to their mother, and tears flowed down their bodies.

The ground where the brahmin walked was steep and rocky, with thorns piercing his body and feet, his wounds were painful, as if seeing bitter and spicy fruits. The brahmin's skin and bones were connected, while the two children's skin and flesh were lustrous, and their complexions returned to normal.
When they returned home, they laughed with joy and said:
'I have obtained two slaves for you, a man and a woman, to do as you command.'
His wife saw the children and said:
'They are not slaves, these children are well-proportioned, with soft and tender hands and feet, unfit for hard labor. I will take them to sell and buy some slaves to do the work.'
Again, at his wife's urging, he wanted to go to another country.
The gods confused his way and he ended up in his own country.
The people recognized him and all said:
'This is the prince's son!
The great king's grandson!'
Sobbing, they went to the palace gate to report.
The king called the brahmin and brought the children into the palace. The palace people, from the oldest to the youngest, all sighed.
The king called for them to be held, but the two children did not go to him.
The king said:
'Why is that?'
The children said:
'Formerly we were the prince's sons, now we are slaves.
How can slaves, lowly as we are, sit on the king's lap?'
He asked the brahmin:
'How did you obtain these children?'
He replied with the facts.
He said:
How much is the child worth?
Before the brahman could answer, the grandson Sun Zhao said:
The boy is worth a thousand silver coins and a hundred oxen;
the girl is worth two thousand gold coins and two hundred cows.
The king said:
The boy is tall but lowly, the girl is young but noble.
Is there any reason for this?
He replied:

The prince is both sage and benevolent, benefiting the two polarities and the world rejoices in following him, like a child relying on a parent. He has obtained the bright plan for the world, yet is seen being far banished to abandon himself in the mountains and marshes, with tigers, wolves, and poisonous insects as his neighbors, eating fruits and wearing grass, with thunder and rain frightening people. Wealth and goods are merely grass and trifles, yet he is seen being discarded. Therefore, it is known that the boy is lowly.

The daughters of the common people, if they have beautiful features and live in the deep palace, sleep on silk quilts, covered with jeweled curtains, wearing the finest clothes in the world, and eating the tribute offerings of the land, then they are noble women.
The king said:
'An eight-year-old child has the discussions of a lofty scholar, let alone his father?'
The palace people, from the highest to the lowest, heard his admonitions and all raised their voices in grief.
The brahman said:
'One thousand silver coins, and a hundred male and female oxen.
If you give them, it is good. If not, then I will leave.'
The king said:
'Yes.'
He immediately hired them as requested, and the brahman left.
The king held his two grandsons on his lap, and said:
'Before, you would not come to be held, but now you come so quickly?'
He replied:
'Before, I was a slave, but now I am the king's grandson.'
He said:
'While your father was in the mountains, what did you eat to sustain yourselves?'
Both children said:
'We provide for ourselves with wild vegetables and tree fruits.
We play with the birds and beasts every day, and have no sorrowful thoughts.'
The king sent messengers to welcome them.
The messengers followed the path. In the mountains, the trees bent and stretched, as if they were bowing and rising, and the birds cried sadly in mournful tones.
The prince said:
'What auspicious signs are these?'
His wife lay on the ground and said:
'Father's intentions have been explained, the messengers have come to welcome us, and the spirits rejoice, thus these auspicious signs have arisen.'
The wife herself lay on the ground as if dead, and only rose to bow to the king's order when the messengers arrived.
The messengers said:
'The king and the queen have lost their appetite and are weeping. Their bodies are wasting away day by day, and they long to see the prince.'
The prince looked around, longing for the trees and flowing springs in the mountains, held back his tears, and ascended the carriage.

When the messenger left, the whole country rejoiced. They cleaned the roads, set up canopies, burned incense, scattered flowers, played music, and held banners and canopies. The whole country rushed to celebrate the Buddha's immeasurable longevity.
The prince entered the city, bowed his head in apology, and inquired about the king's well-being.
The king then entrusted the country's treasures to the prince, encouraging him to practice generosity.

The impoverished people from neighboring countries came to submit, just as the myriad streams return to the ocean.ğŸ”½Even the long-standing enemies bowed and declared their submission, offering tribute and gifts.
Even the bandits became benevolent, and thieves competed in giving. Weapons were put away, and prisons were destroyed.
All beings enjoyed lasting peace, and the ten directions praised it as good.

Accumulating virtue without rest, he eventually attained the status of a TathÄgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened One, a One of Proper and Universal Knowledge, a Supreme Trainer, a Teacher of Gods and Men, an Enlightened and World-Honored Buddha, and became the king of the multitude of sages.
